snippet.textDisplay:
I don't like the idea of sitting on top of anything pressurized to 700 bar, let alone a tank full of rocket fuel (hydrogen is used to propel rockets after all) while going down the road. What if someone crashes into the car or say some road debris tumbles out from a lorry in front of me and punctures the tank I am sitting on top of? I was reading that new sales of the Mirai has already been banned in some European countries due to a large fueling station explosion that set off the airbags in a regular ICE car going down the road a fairly good distance away and injured the people inside even though the car didn't hit anything; it was all the massive blast wave coming off of this hydrogen explosion.

This is another reason the Mirai is kind of dead on arrival, whatever energy source you have, it costs money. When buying a car it is good to look at what it will cost to drive the vehicle through its whole life. With a Tesla Model 3 that is supposed to be 500,000 to 800,000 km before the main battery needs replacement. With the Mirai, that is whenever the fuel cell breaks outside of warranty on say going over a big pothole, the car bottoms out, and the super expensive fuel cell cracks, but let's say it somehow makes it 300,000 km. Over the life of the Tesla, well actually a lot of Tesla owners charge at home and especially those in sunny climates (obviously far far away from the UK) with a few extra solar panels on their roofs to cover the car usage, this cost for power is not much at all. For the Mirai, which gets its hydrogen from a very energy intensive fossil fuel reforming process, in addition to wrecking the environment freeing the hydrogen in this super intensive process, it is going to cost an enormous amount of money in fuel to go 300,000 km, especially if that fuel is not heavily subsidized to bring down the costs. (Then again subsidies are everyone pays for your gas including you so the share of the price you put in at the pump is less.) Even doing renewables and doing electrolysis from water, you kind of have to cover the whole planet in solar panels and wind farms and such because it takes at least 6x as many of them to make the fuel for the Mirai as it does for the Tesla. Really by the time you make it 300,000 km in the Mirai, you could have gone for the fully tricked out Tesla Model X and still saved a fortune in the Model X at the 300,000 km mark and still keep driving the Model X for years and years where the Mirai the fuel cell would have cracked before then, and be out of warranty, so new car time in the event the car doesn't say corrode out high pressure parts with the super corrosive, super highly compressed rocket fuel inside and blown up, killing the driver and everyone in the general vicinity first.

On the electrify road part, a US study during the Obama administration by Oak Ridge labs said the tech we use to wirelessly charge our phones would cost ~$80 billion US to make the cars and trucks around the country capable of driving perpetually around the country. (Of course if everyone used this, the end system would be significantly more, but it would take a while to get to this point.) If you think about what all that oil and associated oil wars cost, this cost is nothing at all, plus once it is there, it keeps going year after year for the most part. The reason it is not some insane number is you can go on batteries on the surface streets and then just have this system in the main thoroughfares.

snippet.textDisplay: There are a few inaccuracies here.  First, the car does not have laptop batteries.  Laptops definitely do not use cylindrical cells that are 18mm in diameter and 65mm in length.  Also, his supercharging stop wasn't charging slow because the number of people at the stall, but rather because he was at a 75% state of charge, which is past the point at which supercharging slows down.  It would have continued to get slower as he charged the car closer to full.
snippet.textOriginal: There are a few inaccuracies here.  First, the car does not have laptop batteries.  Laptops definitely do not use cylindrical cells that are 18mm in diameter and 65mm in length.  Also, his supercharging stop wasn't charging slow because the number of people at the stall, but rather because he was at a 75% state of charge, which is past the point at which supercharging slows down.  It would have continued to get slower as he charged the car closer to full.

snippet.textDisplay:
The new ultracharge can charge car batteries in just 15 minutes to give a 400km range (350KW EVBox Troniq). Even a 2 minute charge like the hydrogen will give you more than enough range for driving around the city for a day. Electric with battery is the way forward. The batteries are also getting lighter and smaller every year, giving more range.
There are only a handful of hydrogen refilling stations in the entire UK (about 10 last time I checked) and hydrogen costs more to drive (2-3 times as much). It also is a much more inefficient way of electricity production and therfore worse for the environment.

snippet.textDisplay:
If people want to campaign for the death of IC engines, EV’s should all be power capped. If it’s truly about the environment then let’s make electric cars as slow as possible. Does anyone else see the contradiction of a tesla? 10sec 1/4 mile bragging rights & able to drain all that precious battery energy as quickly as possible. You know, the same energy that’s come from burning a percentage of fossil fuel still.

Shouldn’t they all be slow and all about power management? Bit like having a torch, you can navigate about at night on low for a week of evenings or whack it on Turbo and drain the battery in 5 minutes.

snippet.textDisplay:
Bit of a shame that James didn’t explain HOW hydrogen is generated - via Wikipedia (“Hydrogen Production”)

“As of 2018, the majority of hydrogen (∼95%) is produced from fossil fuels by steam reforming or partial oxidation of methane and coal gasification with only a small quantity by other routes such as biomass gasification or electrolysis of water.”

Now the argument will be, build more hydrogen cars so the cost to use water electrolysis will make more sense - water-based electrolysis accounts for around than 4%.

Unfortunately that’s now how energy companies work. They maximize profit based on a “fuel stack” - all energies from renewables through natural gas, oil to the most base crude, are sold as a “stack” to energy companies. Prices are set through the total stack cost. Petroleum products occupy most of the stack.

Electrolysis requires new infrastructure and technologies not yet available. Battery development is already in full-swing and costs have dropped nearly to the magic $100/kWh cost for gas parity. This means very soon, we won’t need oil, which endangers the oil economy as we know it. Which is not necessarily a bad thing.

The equation is a lot more complicated than James’s argument - in fact, you can say he skipped over this part entirely just to allow Hydrogen a bit of parity with BEVs. Which is a shame, as its factually incorrect and only muddies the discussion.

Now the argument will be, build more hydrogen cars so the cost to use water electrolysis will make more sense - water-based electrolysis accounts for around than 4%.

Unfortunately that’s now how energy companies work. They maximize profit based on a “fuel stack” - all energies from renewables through natural gas, oil to the most base crude, are sold as a “stack” to energy companies. Prices are set through the total stack cost. Petroleum products occupy most of the stack.

Electrolysis requires new infrastructure and technologies not yet available. Battery development is already in full-swing and costs have dropped nearly to the magic $100/kWh cost for gas parity. This means very soon, we won’t need oil, which endangers the oil economy as we know it. Which is not necessarily a bad thing.

The equation is a lot more complicated than James’s argument - in fact, you can say he skipped over this part entirely just to allow Hydrogen a bit of parity with BEVs. Which is a shame, as its factually incorrect and only muddies the discussion.

snippet.textDisplay:
Never thought I'd say this of you of all the TG/GT presenters but your seating position bothers me. At the end of the day I don't care as long as you're comfortable (and I trust you've driven enough to figure out where you're comfortable) but the lean back arms straight driving position just bugs me... This coming from someone who does the gangsta lean more often than I care admit. Haha

Strangely doesn't bother me when my friends do it, so maybe it's a video thing, but does here.

At the end of the day, you do you... I'll keep watching cause the content is great. Just thought I'd join the internet circus and bitch and moan about SOMETHING!

Great shit as always. Can't want for the Japan series!

Edit: the big thing that will dictate the direction of electric cars one way or the other, in my opinion, is less populous (population per mile) and larger countries... Here, state side, only California's population centers really offer enough infrastructure to support an ev beyond local trips. I live in a fairly populous area of the country (New England) and my friends and I just did a 350 mile round trip day trip to hit up some stores and breweries... Longer than the range of most evs and I never once saw a convenient charging station to any one of our stops (maybe we could have stopped 5 miles away from out destination, or took a 45 min charging break on the way, but neither of those are as convenient as filling up with gas in a traditional car... And again this area is pretty well populated vs the rest of the country).

Now I am probably in the minotory that I can a) afford and b) have space for multiple vehicles... I look forward to buying an ev for trips when it makes sense. I look forward to the Ford mach-e (though as a mustang owner I loathe that crossover thing being called a mustang... it's sacrilege). At the same time though I realize this country either needs a total overhaul ( we've needed one for years) or evs will never really take off outside the context of local travel vehicles (unless the owner can afford/keep 2 cars)
snippet.textOriginal:
Never thought I'd say this of you of all the TG/GT presenters but your seating position bothers me. At the end of the day I don't care as long as you're comfortable (and I trust you've driven enough to figure out where you're comfortable) but the lean back arms straight driving position just bugs me... This coming from someone who does the gangsta lean more often than I care admit. Haha 

Strangely doesn't bother me when my friends do it, so maybe it's a video thing, but does here.

At the end of the day, you do you... I'll keep watching cause the content is great. Just thought I'd join the internet circus and bitch and moan about SOMETHING!

Great shit as always. Can't want for the Japan series!

Edit: the big thing that will dictate the direction of electric cars one way or the other, in my opinion, is less populous (population per mile) and larger countries... Here, state side, only California's population centers really offer enough infrastructure to support an ev beyond local trips. I live in a fairly populous area of the country (New England) and my friends and I just did a 350 mile round trip day trip to hit up some stores and breweries... Longer than the range of most evs and I never once saw a convenient charging station to any one of our stops (maybe we could have stopped 5 miles away from out destination, or took a 45 min charging break on the way, but neither of those are as convenient as filling up with gas in a traditional car... And again this area is pretty well populated vs the rest of the country). 

Now I am probably in the minotory that I can a) afford and b) have space for multiple vehicles... I look forward to buying an ev for trips when it makes sense. I look forward to the Ford mach-e (though as a mustang owner I loathe that crossover thing being called a mustang... it's sacrilege). At the same time though I realize this country either needs a total overhaul ( we've needed one for years) or evs will never really take off outside the context of local travel vehicles (unless the owner can afford/keep 2 cars)

snippet.textDisplay:
You can dispense hydrogen from the existing fuel stations? How on earth? Transportation of Hydrogen isn't as easy as pumping it in the truck at the factory, drive to the fuel station, pump it into the tank of the fuel station.
trucks can transport less than a tenth of hydrogen compared to regular fuel. Pipelines are a bad idea too, as they'll loose a lot of hydrogen on the way.
On bigger scales, hydrogen has to be produced at the fuel station and that needs a heckton of power

snippet.textDisplay: Outside of Western Europe? As it stands now you can not drive from one side of America or South America top to bottom or Australia or Eastern Europe with an all Electric Car in anything remotely reasonable never mind almost all of Africa. You might as well be burning coal dust or have a steam powered car. Just look at what the "Green" industry did to Spain. When I can make a 1200 mile trip in 12 hours including recharging we can revisit all electric. Seriously though we need to be able to do at least 330 miles which is 55 mph x 6 hours of driving and we should be able to do it while pulling a 1500lbs. trailer through the mountains on a single charge. That is not at all extreme and is rather tame for a gasoline of diesel powered car in America. It needs to be fully recharged in 30 minutes so that it can be done at a rest stop or large gas station while you freshen up and grab a bite to eat. That is the bar minimum of acceptable range and usage anything less than that and it is might as well be an inner city only car for those people that live in old mega cities on the coasts. Range, Towing, Hauling, Recharge time, availability of parts so I can repair it myself, Toyota legendary durability are what I think of as the bare minimums. In many ways a Trendy Tesla is a step backwards!
snippet.textOriginal: Outside of Western Europe? As it stands now you can not drive from one side of America or South America top to bottom or Australia or Eastern Europe with an all Electric Car in anything remotely reasonable never mind almost all of Africa. You might as well be burning coal dust or have a steam powered car. Just look at what the "Green" industry did to Spain. When I can make a 1200 mile trip in 12 hours including recharging we can revisit all electric. Seriously though we need to be able to do at least 330 miles which is 55 mph x 6 hours of driving and we should be able to do it while pulling a 1500lbs. trailer through the mountains on a single charge. That is not at all extreme and is rather tame for a gasoline of diesel powered car in America. It needs to be fully recharged in 30 minutes so that it can be done at a rest stop or large gas station while you freshen up and grab a bite to eat. That is the bar minimum of acceptable range and usage anything less than that and it is might as well be an inner city only car for those people that live in old mega cities on the coasts. Range, Towing, Hauling, Recharge time, availability of parts so I can repair it myself, Toyota legendary durability are what I think of as the bare minimums. In many ways a Trendy Tesla is a step backwards!

snippet.textDisplay: I think you hi the nail on the head at the end; the most important quesion for witch car will be the future will be: "What will gas stations do?" If they, like now here in Blgium, do nothing; well then gogo baterycars. But if they deside to invest masavely in hydrogenpomps; then those cars (could) make it faster. But I'm a hughe fan off Tesla, and for me the top reason to go for baterycars is you can charge at home! And yes, there is the question what to do if you can't charge at home, well only these people will have to make a dissision witch car is the best for them. Can they charge at work, or near home, then maybe batery still can win. Also the "new" baterys are comming soon, so maybe they'll can go a week without charging there car, and have a chargestation in use with 6 or 7 other people and charge 1 night a week. The possebilatys are endless, so only the future will have the awnser. But still a great video.

snippet.textDisplay: well.. just dropping my two cents, batteries sucks, heavy, probably won't be much better in the near decade (or two..., because, electricity physics reasons), H2... don't even get me started about it, it's just the most unstable element we know, has the widest UEL-LEL range, it's way to costly to break it out of gas (gas, not gasoline) or water, has to be cryo (boiling temp is... 243C, negative) and compressed to 700 to 1200bar of pressure... IMHO, the best, was to combine both worlds, to avoid having an ev shopping cart for the daily commute (expensive shopping cart) and a car for travelling, moving away from diesel, is one heck of a big mistake, and those raising their fists against oil companies, are just doing them a favor to switch to BEV, H2EV or gasoline. Hauling those materials around the world, will need more ships in the sea, hauling batteries, new and used, will need more fuel too. Oil companies never get screwed by any means of fueling your car. Think about it.

Think about it.
